entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
Matt Corallo brought up an intriguing solution to the sequencing dilemma in the realm of Bitcoin development, focusing on a dual-pronged approach that could significantly impact script path spending. He proposes the introduction of the first PCQ (Probabilistic Constant-time Queries) scheme tailored for tapscript, which is a crucial component of Bitcoin's scripting capabilities, enhancing its flexibility and security. This innovative strategy involves implementing a soft fork that would disable one or more NUMS (Nothing-Up-My-Sleeve Numbers) points. Interestingly, under current cryptographic assumptions, such a move would be non-confiscatory, meaning it wouldn't forcibly take away or devalue existing assets within the system.
This approach offers a safeguard for users and developers, allowing them to engage with the new scheme without the immediate concern of community consensus freezing key path spending. It addresses a critical fear among participants regarding the potential market value implications for their coins, should they become early or repeated victims of frozen assets due to poor key management or other issues. By sidestepping these concerns, Corallo's proposal aims to foster a more secure and user-friendly environment for Bitcoin's evolution, ensuring that advancements in scripting and transaction validation do not come at the expense of participant confidence or asset integrity.
